Flower drop-above 42 degC. Optimum temp. for seed germination-29 degC & do not germinate below 17 0 C

column4: Average temperature degC.high night and day temp. 22-24 & 33-35 markedly reduce fruit set and yield
column11: *2,4-D @2 ppm- -enhances fruit setting -earliness -Parthenocarpy -advanced fruit formation *Tetracycline-@ 1000 ppm to check mycoplasma

column4: Above 320 & below 130 C-dangerous
column11: *2,4-D @ 2 ppm & NAA @ 1ppm-for fruitset. *Bo-for crackingNAA @ 20-40 ppm - to reduce flower & fruit drop *NAA @ 50 ppm improve fruit quality/taste *Ethrel-@ 600 ppm during fruiting- for ripening & colour *Bo-To avoid fruit cracking GA3 for earlt & uniform germination *Cycocel-seedling hardening

column8: Male-45-46 days(20-21st node) Female-50-52 days(24-25th node)
column11: *Ethrel -@ 200 ppm, seed soaking/hrdifferentiation of female flowers, *GA3-@ 100 ppm seed soaking- enhances germination, BA @ 25 ppm, seed soaking differentiation of Female flowers

column4: During transformation phase from veg. to curding & curd dev. climate/temp. plays vital role though some devations are attributed to light & water condition. It is physiologically different crop in cole group due to intermediate phase of curding betweeen veg. & generative.Curding from 5 0 C to 28-30 0 C, however, for transformation certain amount of vegetative growth w/be necessary to pass over juvenile phase: optimum is 23 0 C. Tropical crop- curding at 15-20 0 C. When tropical varieties grown in low temp. not only they button quickly after paasing juvenile phase but leads to riceyness to green bud formation.For veg. growth: few degree higher than optimum needed for curd dev.(10-15 days), temp. should not fluctuate too much -deteriorates.
column11: *GA3 effect: more pronounced when curd initiation delayed by high temp.(regulates harvesting time)

column4: Temp. is more imp. Than day length.In our region it is grown in milder winter(E & W parts).Most of Europian cvs. under this condition do not form tight heads(loose & open heads)-reason for poor yield in India. long cold period induces plant to bolt sooner. optimum temp. for growth & heading 15-20 0 C above 25 0 C growth arrested

Adapted to cool or moderate climate At 20-25 deg C uptake of nutrients was greater and dry matter content was higher, but at still higher temp. of 25-30 0 C root deformation occurs.During hot weather root becomes tough & pungent before reasching edible size.It was noted that yield & quality rose with light intensity

Like radish Optimum temeperature range is 20-25deg C. Seed stalk formation results when subjected to temperature of 12.2-21.1 0 C.Plants grown continuosly at temp. range of 21.1-26.7 0 C fail to develop flower primordia. It is for this reason the seeds of European types of carrot are produced only in the hills of India ,where the winter is severe.
column7: *M+G19H- @ 50 ppm, at 2 &4 leaf stage-Improves % of Female flowers & fruit quality. *TIBA @25-50 ppm at 2 & 4 leaf stage-improves flowering & fruit setting . *Bo@ 2-3 ppm at 2 & 4 leaf stage controls cracking. *Ethephon@250ppm seed soaking- M/F ratio lowest
column11: *Seed soaking inMn(0.02%) & B (0.01%) for 24 hrs gives better germination & thicker stand of larger roots *IBA@ 50 ppm seed soaking for 12 hrs improves root carotene ,Seed treatment with ZnSO4- increase yield

column4: It grows well in warm weather,but it attains best colour, texture & quality in a cool weather.Excessivelt hot weather causes -zoning- the appearance of alternating light & dark red concentric circles in the root.They sensitive to low temperature(4.5-10 0 C), if exposed to such temp. for 15 days , bolting likely to occur before the roots reach marketable size..Requires abundant sunshine for development of storage roots.
column11: *Apply manganese sulphate when grown in alkaline soil.

column4: Grown in mild cilmate without extremes of low & high temp.The plants at early stage can withstand low temp. Requires 20-25 0 C for germination.For vegetative growth-low temp. & short photoperiod (13- 21 0 C) For bulb development- relatively high temp & long photoperiod(15.6-25.1 0 C)
column11: *Application of MH before harvest enhances the storage life * Application of Zinc at 2-3 ppm significantly increses the yield and enhances quality of bulbs by increasing TSS, sugars & ascorbic acid.
column12: Rabi-25-30 T, In Kh comparatively low

column4: Warm seson crop, thrives best between 21-35 0 C.It cannot withstand heavy rainfall & waterloggging.Diff cvs respond differently to temp. and day length & thus there are distinct cvs for spring-summer & rainy seasons.
column11: *MH (50-200 ppm)-before flowering- increase pod yield. *NAA @ 10 ppm at flowering and a week later -improves pod filling and fruit setting

column4: Tropical crop preferring warm climate.The extent to which the crop can stand the heat can be substantiated by the fact that it is grown during summer in arid zones of Rajasthan and Haryana.It prefers long day condition for growth and short day for for induction of flowering. Kharif crop yields better because irrigation has been found to enhance bud production
column11: *Spraying Sodium Molybdate -at 15 & 30 DAS (0.15%)gives better yield. *Cycocel-500 ppm, 25 DAS improves yield

column4: Cultivated throughout the year in the region where mild climate prevails., withstands frost & tolerate warm weather,but high temp. leads to early bolting without giving sufficient cuttings & leaves pass edible stage quickly.
column7: Being leafy veg. require more N for crown(leaves0 growth,100 Kg N/ha with 2 foliar application(2-3 Kg N/ha) gives best results
column9: 3-4 weeks DAS, subsequent cuttings at 15-20 days interval.

column4: Melons require tropical climate with fairly high temperature of 35-40 degC during fruit dev.susceptible to to dew & cold. For sweetness & flavour-cool nights, warm days with low humidity is ideal for accumulation of sugar
